text: UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
label: HH1

text: DISTRICT OF CONNECTICUT
label: HH2

text: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
label: BODY

text: SHAMAR A. THORNTON
label: BODY

text: RULING ON DEFENDANT’S MOTION
label: HH1

text: TO SUPPRESS AND DEFENDANT’S REQUEST FOR A HEARING
label: HH2

text: For the reasons set forth below, defendant Shamar A.
label: BODY

text: Thorton’s Motion to Suppress (Doc. No. 13) and his Motion for a
label: BODY

text: Hearing (Doc. No. 14) are being denied.
label: BODY

text: FACTUAL AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
label: HH1

text: On or about October 5, 2005, the Hartford DEA Task Force
label: BODY

text: received information from a confidential informant regarding an
label: BODY

text: individual believed to be engaged in the sale and distribution of
label: BODY

text: crack cocaine in the Bowles Park area of Hartford.  The
label: BODY

text: confidential informant provided a physical description of the
label: BODY

text: suspect and a description of his vehicle.  On October 5, 2005, an
label: BODY

text: individual who matched the physical description provided by the
label: BODY

text: confidential informant was observed by the investigating agents
label: BODY

text: entering 251 Nahum Drive and exiting a few minutes later.  The
label: BODY

text: subject, later identified as defendant Shamar A. Thornton was
label: BODY

text: then observed entering the vehicle described by the confidential
label: BODY

text: informant and driving away from 251 Nahum Drive.  The
label: BODY

text: investigating agents observed the vehicle roll through a stop
label: BODY

text: sign and fail to signal when turning.  While the defendant was
label: BODY

text: stopped in traffic, he appeared to notice the investigating
label: BODY

text: agents’ unmarked vehicles, and he was observed checking his
label: BODY

text: mirrors and looking around as if looking for an escape route.
label: BODY

text: When the defendant put his vehicle in reverse, the investigating
label: BODY

text: agents approached the vehicle.  The defendant appeared to panic,
label: BODY

text: and Task Force Agent Burgos observed the defendant stuff
label: BODY

text: something down the back of his pants.  The defendant was removed
label: BODY

text: from the vehicle and handcuffed.
label: BODY

text: Task Force Agent Plourde, a certified K-9 handler, directed
label: BODY

text: his K-9 to sniff the defendant’s vehicle and person.  The K-9
label: BODY

text: alerted on the defendant’s buttocks area.  As Burgos was about to
label: BODY

text: conduct a pat down of the defendant’s person, the defendant
label: BODY

text: stated that he had stuffed a small amount of crack cocaine down
label: BODY

text: his pants and that he was sorry.  As a crowd began to assemble in
label: BODY

text: the area, the investigating agents decided to transport the
label: BODY

text: defendant to a parking lot approximately one block away. Burgos
label: BODY

text: subsequently located and seized from the defendant’s person a
label: BODY

text: plastic bag containing 25 knotted plastic bags, each of which
label: BODY

text: contained a white rock-like substance.  A field test confirmed
label: BODY

text: the presence of cocaine.
label: BODY

text: Plourde and other investigating agents then proceeded to 251
label: BODY

text: Nahum Drive, Apartment 1A, where they met Marquila Alexander, the
label: BODY

text: defendant’s girlfriend.  Alexander confirmed that she lived in
label: BODY

text: the apartment with the defendant.  Alexander provided written
label: BODY

text: consent to search the apartment.  In a bedroom dresser drawer
label: BODY

text: containing male underwear and documents and letters belonging to
label: BODY

text: the defendant, the investigating agents found a Rossi .38 caliber
label: BODY

text: revolver.  In addition, a substance that later field tested
label: BODY

text: positive for cocaine and .38 caliber ammunition were seized from
label: BODY

text: a safe located inside a bedroom closet.
label: BODY

text: The defendant was transported to the DEA’s Hartford field
label: BODY

text: office, where he was advised of his Miranda rights.  He waived
label: BODY

text: his rights and provided a written statement in which he admitted
label: BODY

text: ownership and possession of the crack cocaine, as well as the
label: BODY

text: ammunition and the firearm found at his residence.
label: BODY

text: On February 28, 2006, the defendant was arrested and charged
label: BODY

text: by criminal complaint with Possession of a Firearm by a Convicted
label: BODY

text: Felon.  On March 8, 2006, a Grand Jury sitting in Bridgeport
label: BODY

text: returned a three-count indictment charging the defendant with
label: BODY

text: Possession of a Firearm by a Convicted Felon, in violation of 18
label: BODY

text: U.S.C. § 922(g)(1), Possession with Intent to Distribute 5 or
label: BODY

text: More Grams of Cocaine Base, in violation of 21 U.S.C. §§
label: BODY

text: 841(a)(1) and 841(b)(1)(B), and Possession of a Firearm in
label: BODY

text: Furtherance of a Drug Trafficking Crime, in violation of 21
label: BODY

text: The defendant has moved to suppress (i) the controlled
label: BODY

text: substances seized from his person; (ii) his statement to
label: BODY

text: investigating agents that he stuffed a small amount of crack
label: BODY

text: cocaine down his pants; (iii) objects seized by investigating
label: BODY

text: agents from 251 Nahum Drive, Apartment 1A; and (iv) his oral and
label: BODY

text: written statements made at the DEA’s Hartford field office.
label: BODY

text: II.
label: HH3

text: ARGUMENT
label: H1

text: Request for Evidentiary Hearing
label: BODY

text: It is well settled in the Second Circuit that a defendant
label: BODY

text: seeking to suppress evidence bears the burden of demonstrating
label: BODY

text: that there are disputed issues of fact that would justify an
label: BODY

text: evidentiary hearing.  United States v. Culotta, 413 F.2d 1343,
label: BODY

text: 1345 (2d Cir. 1969); United States v. Gillette, 383 F.2d 843,
label: BODY

text: 848-49 (2d Cir. 1967).  A defendant’s burden is not satisfied by
label: BODY

text: “conclusory, non-particularized allegations of unlawful official
label: BODY

text: behavior.”  United States v. Tracy, 758 F. Supp. 816, 820 (D.
label: BODY

text: Conn. 1991).  Rather, the showing required to justify a hearing
label: BODY

text: must be made by an affidavit of someone with personal knowledge
label: BODY

text: of the underlying facts; a defense attorney’s declarations are
label: BODY

text: insufficient.  Gillette, 383 F.2d at 848-49 (affidavit by defense
label: BODY

text: attorney in support of motion not based on attorney’s personal
label: BODY

text: knowledge was insufficient to create factual issues required to
label: BODY

text: be resolved at an evidentiary hearing); Shaw, 260 F. Supp.2d at
label: BODY

text: 570 (same); United States v. Caruso, 684 F. Supp. 84, 87
label: BODY

text: Experience shows that unless such serious charges are
label: BODY

text: initiated upon the sworn statement of persons having
label: BODY

text: personal knowledge of the facts, a great deal of time of
label: BODY

text: the parties and the Court is frequently wasted upon
label: BODY

text: unnecessary,
label: BODY

text: expensive
label: BODY

text: and
label: BODY

text: protracted
label: BODY

text: suppression
label: BODY

text: hearings, all for the reason that the attorney demanding
label: BODY

text: suppression merely upon his own say-so often discovers
label: BODY

text: only at the hearing that he had been misled by unsworn
label: BODY

text: misrepresentations of his clients, which they would be
label: BODY

text: unwilling to swear to in an affidavit, particularly if
label: BODY

text: they were questioned closely by their counsel and warned
label: BODY

text: of the consequences of perjury.
label: BODY

text: United States v. Garcia, 272 F. Supp. 286, 290 (S.D.N.Y. 1976).
label: BODY

text: A motion to suppress not supported by an affidavit by someone
label: BODY

text: with personal knowledge of the facts may be properly denied
label: BODY

text: without a hearing.   United States v. Ruggiero, 824 F. Supp. 379,
label: BODY

text: 393-94 (S.D.N.Y 1993); United States v. Sierra-Garcia, 760 F.
label: BODY

text: Here, the defendant’s motion is predicated entirely on the
label: BODY

text: unsworn assertions of his counsel.  The defendant argues that the
label: BODY

text: traffic stop was not lawful because he “did not roll through a
label: BODY

text: stop sign . . did not fail to signal while turning and he did not
label: BODY

text: place the car in reverse.”  Mem. in Supp. of Def.’s Mot. to
label: BODY

text: Suppress (Doc. No. 13-2)(“Def.’s Br.”), 2.  The defendant argues
label: BODY

text: further that his statement at the scene of the traffic stop was a
label: BODY

text: product of custodial interrogation and offered without him having
label: BODY

text: received Miranda warnings. Id.  With respect to the search of 251
label: BODY

text: Nahum Drive, the defendant argues that he did not provide consent
label: BODY

text: and he “believes” that Marquila Alexander did not consent
label: BODY

text: voluntarily.  Id.  Lastly, the defendant argues that his
label: BODY

text: statement at the DEA’s Hartford field office was involuntary, and
label: BODY

text: given without him having received his Miranda warnings.  Id.
label: BODY

text: The defendant submits no affidavit or other documentation in
label: BODY

text: support of his motion.
label: BODY

text: The unsupported factual assertions of his counsel are
label: BODY

text: insufficient to warrant an evidentiary hearing or justify the
label: BODY

text: relief requested by the defendant.  Moreover, these unsworn
label: BODY

text: assertions are disputed by statements in the Hartford Police
label: BODY

text: Department incident report and in the sworn affidavit submitted
label: BODY

text: in support of the Criminal Complaint.  See Government’s Resp. to
label: BODY

text: Def.’s Mot. To Suppress and Objection to Def.’s Req. for a Hr’g
label: BODY

text: (Doc. No. 18) (“Government’s Resp.”), Ex. A; Compl., Borysevicz
label: BODY

text: Aff. (Doc. No. 1).  By way of contrast, in the absence of a sworn
label: BODY

text: statement by an affiant with personal knowledge, the defendant
label: BODY

text: has no accountability for the assertions that his counsel has
label: BODY

text: made.
label: BODY

text: The defendant argues that he should not be required to
label: BODY

text: substantiate his claims with a sworn statement because he is at
label: BODY

text: risk for an enhancement for obstruction of justice should he be
label: BODY

text: convicted and the court concludes he proffered a false sworn
label: BODY

text: statement.  The defendant provides no legal support for his
label: BODY

text: request that the court convene an evidentiary hearing without him
label: BODY

text: being required to show that there is a genuine dispute as to a
label: BODY

text: material fact.  However, a key reason for requiring a sworn
label: BODY

text: affidavit is to make the defendant and any other witnesses
label: BODY

text: accountable for their statements to the court.  The investigating
label: BODY

text: agents have asserted the relevant facts in a police incident
label: BODY

text: report and in a sworn affidavit.  The relevant case law requires
label: BODY

text: the same of the defendant.  There is no reasonable basis here to
label: BODY

text: excuse the defendant from satisfying the requirements for being
label: BODY

text: given an evidentiary hearing.
label: BODY

text: B.  The Traffic Stop
label: BODY

text: The defendant argues that, contrary to the representations
label: BODY

text: by the investigating agents, he did not violate traffic
label: BODY

text: regulations. As discussed above, the defendant fails to make a
label: BODY

text: showing that there is a genuine dispute as to this factual issue.
label: BODY

text: Task Force Agents have represented that they observed the
label: BODY

text: defendant roll through a stop sign and turn without first using a
label: BODY

text: turn signal.  “The decision to stop an automobile is reasonable
label: BODY

text: where the police have probable cause to believe that a traffic
label: BODY

text: violation has occurred.”  United States v. Harrell, 268 F.3d 141,
label: BODY

text: 148 (2d. Cir. 2001) (quoting Whren v. United States, 517 U.S.
label: BODY

text: 301.  Here, the records shows that the agents observed the
label: BODY

text: defendant commit traffic violations.
label: BODY

text: If a traffic stop is lawful, the driver and any passenger do
label: BODY

text: not have a Fourth Amendment interest in not being ordered out of
label: BODY

text: the stopped vehicle.  See Pennsylvania v. Mimms, 434 U.S. 106
label: BODY

text: (1977) (once vehicle is lawfully stopped, ordering driver out of
label: BODY

text: car is a de minimis intrusion and driver has no Fourth Amendment
label: BODY

text: interest in not being ordered out of car); Maryland v. Wilson,
label: BODY

text: 519 U.S. 408 (1997) (passengers in lawfully stopped car have no
label: BODY

text: Fourth Amendment interest in not being ordered out of car). Once
label: BODY

text: the defendant’s vehicle was observed violating a traffic
label: BODY

text: regulation, the agents were authorized to stop the vehicle, order
label: BODY

text: the defendant to exit the vehicle and detain him for a reasonable
label: BODY

text: period of time so that the agents could further their
label: BODY

text: investigation.
label: BODY

text: Here, it appears that when the defendant detected the
label: BODY

text: presence of the investigating agents, he put the vehicle in
label: BODY

text: reverse and began to search for an escape route.  As the agents
label: BODY

text: converged on his car, the defendant was observed stuffing
label: BODY

text: something down the back of his pants.  Based on these
label: BODY

text: observations, and considered in light of the fact that the
label: BODY

text: defendant had been described by a reliable informant as a small
label: BODY

text: time crack cocaine dealer, the agents had reasonable suspicion to
label: BODY

text: extend the duration of the detention and investigate further.
label: BODY

text: The Fourth Amendment permits law enforcement officers to initiate
label: BODY

text: investigative stops when they have “reasonable suspicion,
label: BODY

text: supported by articulable facts that criminal activity ‘may be a
label: BODY

text: foot.’” United States v. Sokolow, 490 U.S. 1, 7 (1989) (quoting
label: BODY

text: Terry v. Ohio, 392 U.S. 1, 30 (1968); see also United States v.
label: BODY

text: Cortez, 449 U.S. 411, 417 (“An investigatory stop must be
label: BODY

text: justified by some objective manifestation that the person stopped
label: BODY

text: is, or is about to be, engaged in criminal activity.”).  “[T]he
label: BODY

text: level of suspicion required for a Terry stop is obviously less
label: BODY

text: demanding than that for probable cause.” Sokolow, 490 U.S. at 7
label: BODY

text: (citations omitted).   “Although an officer's reliance on a mere
label: BODY

text: ‘hunch’ is insufficient to justify a stop, the likelihood of
label: BODY

text: criminal activity need not rise to the level required for
label: BODY

text: probable cause, and it falls considerably short of satisfying a
label: BODY

text: preponderance of the evidence standard.” United States v. Arvizu,
label: BODY

text: 534 U.S. 266, 273-274 (2002) (citations omitted).
label: BODY

text: In determining whether the information possessed by a law
label: BODY

text: enforcement officer provided a sufficient basis for a stop, the
label: BODY

text: court is required to look at the totality of the circumstances.
label: BODY

text: Arvizu, 534 U.S. at 273; Alabama v. White, 496 U.S. 325, 330
label: BODY

text: (1990).  “[T]he court must evaluate those circumstances ‘through
label: BODY

text: the eyes of a reasonable and cautious police officer on the
label: BODY

text: scene, guided by his experience and training.’” United States v.
label: BODY

text: Colon, 250 F.3d 130, 134 (2d Cir. 2001) (quoting United States v.
label: BODY

text: Bayless, 201 F.3d 16, 133 (2d Cir. 2000).  The “totality of the
label: BODY

text: circumstances” inquiry permits police officers to “make
label: BODY

text: inferences from and deductions about the cumulative information
label: BODY

text: available to them that might well elude an untrained person.”
label: BODY

text: Arvizu, at 273 (quotations omitted).
label: BODY

text: Here, the record shows that the traffic stop by the
label: BODY

text: investigating agents was supported by reasonable suspicion, as
label: BODY

text: was the extension of the duration of the detention and the
label: BODY

text: further investigation.
label: BODY

text: Search at 251 Nahum Drive.
label: BODY

text: The defendant argues that the search of the apartment he
label: BODY

text: shared with Marquila Alexander at 251 Nahum Drive was conducted
label: BODY

text: without consent.  He argues that he “believes” Alexander’s
label: BODY

text: consent was involuntary.  This is an equivocal and
label: BODY

text: unsubstantiated assertion that cannot justify either an
label: BODY

text: evidentiary hearing or suppression of the items seized from the
label: BODY

text: apartment.  Also, the defendant’s argument about fear of an
label: BODY

text: enhancement for obstruction of justice should he be found guilty
label: BODY

text: is not relevant here because an affidavit would be submitted by
label: BODY

text: Alexander, not by the defendant.
label: BODY

text: In addition, Alexander’s written consent to a search of the
label: BODY

text: apartment flatly contradicts the defendant’s unsupported
label: BODY

text: assertion.  See Government’s Resp., Ex. B.  On the consent form,
label: BODY

text: Alexander represents that she was not “threatened, nor forced in
label: BODY

text: any way” and that she “freely consent[s] to this search.”  Id.
label: BODY

text: Defendant’s Statements During the Traffic Stop.
label: BODY

text: The defendant argues that he did not say to Burgos that he
label: BODY

text: had stuffed a small amount of crack cocaine down his pants, and
label: BODY

text: also that, in any event, he was not given Miranda warnings.  See
label: BODY

text: Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966).  Both of the arguments
label: BODY

text: by defense counsel are unsupported.
label: BODY

text: “Miranda warnings are required only where there has been
label: BODY

text: such a restriction on a person’s freedom as to render him ‘in
label: BODY

text: custody’.”  Oregon v. Mathiason, 429 U.S. 492, 495 (1977).
label: BODY

text: “[T]he initial determination of custody depends on the objective
label: BODY

text: circumstances of the interrogation, not on the subjective views
label: BODY

text: harbored by either the interrogating officers or the persons
label: BODY

text: being questioned.”  Stansbury v. California, 511 U.S. 318, 323
label: BODY

text: (1994).  “[A] custodial setting is one providing ‘inherently
label: BODY

text: coercive pressures that tend to undermine the individual’s will
label: BODY

text: to resist and to compel him to speak.’” United States v.
label: BODY

text: Mitchell, 966 F.2d 92, 98 (2d Cir. 1992).
label: BODY

text: The record at this point demonstrates that the defendant’s
label: BODY

text: admission to possessing crack cocaine was not in response to a
label: BODY

text: custodial interrogation.  As Burgos was conducting a pat down of
label: BODY

text: the defendant’s person, the defendant stated that he had stuffed
label: BODY

text: a small amount of crack cocaine down his pants and that he was
label: BODY

text: sorry.  Thus, the defendant’s statement was not in response to
label: BODY

text: any questioning by an investigating agent.  “The fundamental
label: BODY

text: import of the privilege while an individual is in custody is not
label: BODY

text: whether he is allowed to talk to the police without the benefit
label: BODY

text: of warnings and counsel, but whether he can be interrogated . . .
label: BODY

text: Volunteered statements of any kind are not barred by the Fifth
label: BODY

text: Amendment and their admissibility is not affected by our holding
label: BODY

text: today.”  Miranda, at 478.
label: BODY

text: It is clear therefore that the special procedural
label: BODY

text: safeguards outlined in Miranda are required not where a
label: BODY

text: suspect is simply taken into custody, but rather where a
label: BODY

text: suspect in custody is subjected to interrogation.
label: BODY

text: ‘Interrogation,’ as conceptualized in the Miranda
label: BODY

text: opinion, must reflect a measure of compulsion above and
label: BODY

text: beyond that inherent in custody itself.
label: BODY

text: Rhode Island v. Innis, 446 U.S. 291, 300 (1980).  Therefore, even
label: BODY

text: if the defendant was in custody for purpose of Miranda warnings,
label: BODY

text: the record as it now stands shows that the statement offered by
label: BODY

text: the defendant was not elicited during an interrogation.
label: BODY

text: Defendant’s Post-Arrest Statement
label: BODY

text: The defendant also argues that his oral and written
label: BODY

text: statements to investigating agents following his arrest were
label: BODY

text: involuntary and were not preceded by Miranda warnings.  This
label: BODY

text: assertion by defense counsel is also unsupported.  The defendant
label: BODY

text: argues that the investigating agents told him that by providing a
label: BODY

text: statement, “he would save from a federal prosecution Marquila
label: BODY

text: Alexander and also save her child from DCF custody proceedings.”
label: BODY

text: Def.’s Br. 2.  However, the defendant’s written statement
label: BODY

text: contains his representation that he provided the statement
label: BODY

text: “voluntarily, without threat or promise made to me by anyone.  I
label: BODY

text: have been read my rights and I understand them.” Government’s
label: BODY

text: Resp., Ex. C.  In addition, the incident report states that
label: BODY

text: Special Agent Borysevicz advised the defendant of his Miranda
label: BODY

text: rights from a preprinted card, that the defendant acknowledged
label: BODY

text: that he understood his rights, and that this was witnessed by
label: BODY

text: Plourde.  See Government’s Resp., Ex. A at 4.  Based on the
label: BODY

text: record, the court concludes that the defendant’s post-arrest
label: BODY

text: statement was voluntary and preceded by Miranda warnings.
label: BODY

text: III. CONCLUSION
label: HH3

text: For the reasons set forth above, Defendant’s Motion to
label: BODY

text: Suppress (Doc. No. 13) and Defendant’s Motion for a Hearing (Doc.
label: BODY

text: No. 14) are hereby DENIED.
label: BODY

text: It is so ordered.
label: BODY

text: Dated this 16th day of November 2006 at Hartford,
label: BODY

text: Connecticut.
